title: Monday, 14th August, 2017

PM11:05am

https://www.ft.com...-8924-00144feabdc0

It was, in the words of one veteran of African mining, “the jackpot”. In April 2010, the conglomerate of a buccaneering Israeli billionaire who made his fortune trading diamonds across Africa and beyond, struck a deal to sell a 51 per cent stake of its mining interests in Guinea for $2.5bn.

Even by the standards of Beny Steinmetz, the sale to Vale of Brazil, the world’s biggest iron ore miner, looked like a handsome return. His company had spent a mere $160m for the rights to mine half of Simandou, a mountain thick with tropical foliage and groaning with iron ore.

Now, however, the group’s prospects in the tiny west African nation that is home to some of the world’s most coveted mineral deposits face a threat. Guinea has reignited a multibillion-dollar tussle for the country’s treasure as the authorities scrutinise mining deals struck under former dictatorships.

The Financial Times has learnt that a government committee has launched a corruption probe and is demanding answers about how Beny Steinmetz Group Resources secured in 2008 the rights to the half of Simandou that had earlier that year been stripped from the Anglo-Australian mining house, Rio Tinto.

PM11:06am

Beny Steinmetz, the Israeli billionaire, has been detained by Israeli police for questioning, his lawyer said on Monday.

Ronen Rosenblum, Mr Steinmetz’s personal lawyer, told the Financial Times that Israeli police had taken him for questioning at a police station in Lod, central Israel, but that he did not yet know whether his client would be formally arrested or taken into court.

This came as Calcalist, the Israeli financial publication, and the Ynet news service reported that five people, including Mr Steinmetz, were arrested by Israeli police in connection with an investigation into alleged fraud and money laundering using false contracts in an unnamed foreign country.

Israeli media reported that Swiss and U.S. authorities were also involved in the investigation.

Calgon Carbon Corporation provides products and services used in the treatment of water and air in municipal,
commercial and industrial processes. The company operates in three segments: Activated Carbon and
Service, Equipment, and Consumer. Calgon is a global leader in the use of activated carbons for water and air
purification, selling its products primarily in the United States , Europe, and Japan. The company was founded
in 1942 and is headquartered in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania.

11:19 am
PM11:19am

At this point you may be wondering what this has to do with our man Oozi Cats. The first thing to note, and one of the
reasons we dug into his past at tall, is that this is a very unusual anglicised spelling. Every other person of the same
name we can find spells it Uzi Katz. For example, a 2002 Globes article on Dai Telecom, which later became Telit,
names the CEO as Uzi Katz.

PM11:20am

The second thing to note is that if you search online for Uzi Katz you are likely to come up with a large number of
strange looking websites with titles like “Professor of English Literature from Boston - Uzi Katz”, “Uzi Katz, civil
engineer from Boston” and “Uzi Katz of Boston”. The funny thing is they all relate to people named Uzi Katz with

PM11:20am

strong links to the city of Boston (our favourite is “Uzi Katz, Boston Dancer”). They also seem to be fake. That is, they
do not appear to relate to real life people. Instead they may be designed to create a smokescreen. The fact that the
registered contact for one has an email address reputation@seo-properties.com (“seo” being short for search engine
optimisation) seems to fit with this.

As in, a couple of companies swap territories with each other so everyone is number one in whatever markets they end up with.

PM11:36am

PM11:36am

11:36 am
BE11:36am

On paper, the JE model is a very efficient way to create a cartel. You only compete up to the point that you know you'll not be number one, then you sell out to whoever's number one.

BE11:37am

Usually in exchange for a regional op somewhere else, where you're number one. It's neat and tidy.

BE11:37am

Anyway, Merrill has a big internet note out this morning.

11:37 am
PM11:38am

(When you launch your Just Eat Eater -- chicken shop platform with webcams in the kitchens -- this thing will fold quickly.)

BE11:38am

We downgraded Just Eat late last year on concerns about UK underlying order growth.
With those concerns abating and strategy in our view improving in relation to delivery,
we move to Buy. With peers’ share prices climbing YTD (GRUB +44%, TKWY +58%)
despite profit downgrades, Just Eat is now the cheapest global takeaway vendor – not
only on earnings metrics but also on Gross Merchandise Value (GMV; the value of orders
processed) – so temporary margin weakness should be looked through. The shares trade
on 3.3/4.1% 2018/19e FCF yield and 1.1x GMV (H1’17 annualised; Table 2), compared to
GRUB at 1.2x and TKWY at 1.3x, despite much lower home market tax rates, underlining
the stock’s valuation. Upgrade to Buy, PO of 740p (prev. 750p) offering 23% upside
potential.

BE11:38am

Sorry for the duff formatting.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Unusually for an upgrade to Buy, we still see downside to near-term consensus earnings
estimates at Just Eat (but upside to revenue). Our 2018E EBITDA is 12% below
Bloomberg consensus (Table 7), following another 6% cut today (Table 6). However, we
think that is anticipated by share price weakness. More importantly, downside should be
temporary, driven by 1) start-up costs in delivery – we factor in a c. £35m discretionary
investment by 2018, offsetting strong incremental profit from the core business. 2) The
start of a new CEO, which we think typically leads to margin guidance conservatism. We
still have a 20% CAGR to EBITDA FY17-20E. UberEats is clearly a concern - which
management is rightly responding to – although job postings suggest its build-out is
now focused more on emerging markets (Table 4) – so near term risk may be priced in.

BE11:38am

More important than near term profits to us is the health of the company’s core UK
division. Growth rates have recovered to high teens (18% in H1), despite minimal boost
as yet from delivery investments. The fact that UK orders per customer continues to
climb – despite a fall in marketing intensity (Chart 3) – suggests the core business with
local independent restaurants is robust. We are cautiously optimistic for H2. Finally, if
JE does get approval for its HungryHouse takeover, this could add ~10% to EBITDA
estimates. If it does not, a buyback/special dividend is a possibility, we think.

BE11:50am

As investor-owned stock tends to change hands less frequently than owner-occupied
housing; this feature of the last two decades stymies transaction levels.

BE11:51am

Plus, obviously, affordability.

11:51 am

The charts below show UK house prices since 1975 (left hand side) and average deposits as
a proportion of purchase price for first time buyers (FTB) and owner occupiers since 1988
(right hand side). As house prices have risen rapidly, so too have deposit requirements,
particularly for FTB.

BE11:52am

Including taxes. There's loads of stuff in there about stamp duty as a percentage and etc.

BE11:52am

So, aren't lower house prices a positive for estate agents?

11:52 am
BE11:53am

As in, if price correlates negatively with volume isn't a lower price good for those reliant on volume?

BE11:53am

Ach, here's Barclays summary anyway.

BE11:53am

Countrywide – focus on debt reduction. We estimate that c30% of the company’s
revenues are dependent on housing transactions (largely estate agency commissions).
Reflecting this and our estimate of the impact of the proposed tenancy fee ban (we
now incorporate this from 1st January 2019), we downgrade our 2017E (20%), 2018E
(11%) and 2019E (30%) EPS forecasts. We forecast no dividends in the next three years
(the company has announced the withdrawal of this year’s interim dividend with the
final dividend under review). The quid pro quo of this is that gearing falls more rapidly
(net debt/EBITDA 1.7x in 2019E, despite the tenancy fee hit). We recognise that other
steps to accelerate debt reduction could reinstate dividends, though Countrywide has
announced that the Lambert Smith Hampton sale is now off the agenda. With the
shares trading on a 2018E PER of 9x (EV/EBITDA c6x), they do not look expensive and
could re-rate as leverage fears are assuaged. We stay EW (PT reduced by 10% to 155p).

11:53 am
BE11:53am

Foxtons – in the eye of the storm, though with no gearing. We estimate that c44% of
the company’s revenues depend on housing volumes. Reflecting weak conditions in
London (the focal point of the housing transactions hiatus), we downgrade our
2017/2019E EPS forecasts by c25% (here, we have previously-incorporated the
proposed tenancy fee ban). To its credit, Foxtons’ balance sheet is unlevered and we
expect it to pay dividends throughout our forecast period. However, the shares are
trading on a 2018E PER of c32x and, with no obvious signs of improvement in
underlying market conditions, we stay UW (PT reduced by 15% to 66p).

BE11:54am

Savills – strength through diversification. Despite the company’s limited exposure to
UK housing transactions (we estimate they drive less than 10% of revenues), we downgrade to
EW (PT 913p) for two reasons. First, the shares have been strong performers in the last
year (up c34% in this period, compared to c14% for the FTSE 250). And second, the
transfer of our Property Services names into our house building coverage raises the
benchmark (our view that strong house building fundamentals remain intact)

11:57 am
BE11:57am

Which goes back to our old argument on here about how to stick Dixons (a business where you buy your TV upfront and pay at the till) together with Carphone (a business where they give you a phone for less than nothing then take your money every month for the next two years.)

BE11:58am

(@Fjp: bang on.)

BE11:59am

Anyway, Deutsche stuck out a counterpoint towards the back of Friday, which reads like this ....

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Q1 sales on 7 September Dixons Carphone shares have sharply de-rated in recent months on concerns about mobile profitability, the quality of last year's earnings, director share sales and broader concerns about the UK economy. We believe these valid concerns are priced in, particularly as we see a number of levers which can be pulled to control profitability. We expect the company to report a reassuring set of Q1 sales on 7 September: a relatively unimportant trading period but nevertheless important for sentiment. The stock trades on Calendar 2017E P/E 7.4x against the UK General Retail sector, which trades on c.13.0x. It trades on EV/NOPAT 9.0x (inc. pension) and its FCF yield of 4.6% should materially improve next year. Buy. Q1 like for like sales growth forecasts: UK +4%, Nordics +1.5%, Greece +0% Q1 (May-July) is a relatively unimportant trading period for Dixons Carphone. However, we think it should provide evidence of positive momentum in the group. In the UK, which accounts for three-quarters of group profits, we expect LFLs of +4%. As set out overleaf, this comprises underlying +1.5% at CurrysPCWorld and 0% at Carphone Warehouse, plus a continued sales benefit from store closures. The performance in mobile should be better than the prior quarter, in part driven by product launches. Priced for challenges It would be an understatement to say the Dixons Carphone share price looks a little unloved. However, we believe the company can meet consensus forecasts for FY Apr-18 (DB Headline PBT £497m, unchanged). In the UK, lower property costs, central cost savings and the re-launch of its consumer services brand should be supportive. Last year the company had to revalue downwards the out of bundle mobile revenues due to EU roaming; this year we expect network receivables to be revalued upwards due to higher revenues after the initial contract term. Its own sensitivity disclosure suggests this could be a c.£25m support. In the Nordics, fewer double running costs in the supply chain and lower store costs (eg shelf-edge pricing), plus currency benefits, should drive profits.
